Hypothetical situation. There's a guy who looks to be about 30 years old, but you suspect that he's really 10,000 years old. A routine doctor's appointment finds nothing odd about him.
 
 What tests might you run to check if someone were really 10,000 years old? Two restirictions: you can't lock him up for 50 years and see if he ages, and you can't do anything that would kill an ordinary person.
 
 An odd question, I know, but I started thinking about it, and it seemed like an interesting scientific puzzle. I would check for bioaccumulating substances, like heavy metals, to see if he had way more than a 30 year old could have. A positive result would be evidence of advanced age, but a negative result wouldn't necessarily mean anything. That which keeps him alive could also get rid of heavy metals. Can anyone else come up with anything?

 Because, as has been explained to you, that only works on non-living organisms. As long as you are taking in carbon, either through eating for animals or via the atmosphere for plants, then your carbon ratios will match those of the atmosphere. It's only after death that radioactive decay becomes a factor, since at that point the C14 is no longer being replenished.

 That would have shown up on the doctor's visit, now wouldn't it? The reasons for thinking he's ancient are irrelevant; call it a hunch.

Try a dentist, Archaeologists assign a probable age to fossil skulls based on tooth wear since tooth enamel is the only substance in the human body not continually replaced. Once your wisdom teeth are through that's it.
 
 Failing that check if they produce a reflection in the mirror, (you may wish to do this before getting too close to their teeth).

 This may not give an answer to the question being sought, but (1) it might give us more reason to suspect his advanced age and (2) it might give us information about aging in general. I'd have the lengths of his telomeres checked. If they're standard for a 30 year old, that still doesn't mean anything, so check again in 10 years when most people show degradation. If he doesn't, then that's at least some support for your hunch.

If he can "magic" away any evidence of age, then he would be indistinguishable from any other 30 year old, so no examination or experimentation would turn up anything out of the ordinary.

0th: Decide whether finding out is actually worth the fuss.
 
 1st: Check for any anomalies in his body. No idea what, but something could be noticeably different. If a difference is actually found, it reinforces his claims and studying the differences might actually allow you to find the actual mechanism.
 
 2nd: Check his story. Ask him about history and compare it to known history, keeping an open mind (memory quality vs. historian's accuracy).
 
 3rd: Occam's razor. Without indications that his story is true, the assumption that he's wrong/lying prevails as it is consistent with real world's large population of liars, delusionals and similar people.
